messages.content:
I want to make proof of the game, that the user will send to the chain, and his score will be stored on the leaderboard. The problem is that other players can reuse this game proof, send it as their own, and also get to the leaderboard. So i want to add the user's public key to proof.  How can I do it? 
Simple - add a public key as public input to zkprogram and check
```
pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey)
```
will work, or is it easy to generate new proof using an existing one?
pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey) only asserts that pubKey equals itself
is pubKey a public or private input?
Its public, so i can check it with msg.sender. Does it matter?
are we talking in the context of protokit, zk program or smart contract?
zkprogram. Later i want to pass this proof to protokit function
why not verify a signature of the public key within the zk program, and expose the public key as public output?
and then in your runtime, use the output's public key to compare it with the tx sender for example
How can I verify public key, with this - pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey)?
get a signature from auro using sign fields, and verify that signature using the public key in the zk program
signature.verify(pubkey, message) // or something like that
Yeah, it should work. Thanks

But also I want to get a little more detailed about reason of this question: 
As i understand zkproofs - something like this `pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey)`, will add one more constrain. So it is + 1 linear equation.  Then we run all of this equation over elliptic curve, and than we make some kind of magic(that I dont fully understand for now) that makes the proof succinct.  Without last step `pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey)` is useless as long as we can just change this one linear equation with ours and get the new proof. But with this "succinct magic" - is pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey) valid check, or is it as easy to fake? 
`signature.verify(pubkey, message)` - is valid solution, but as i understand from previous questions here, we need to do this kind of check anyway on smart contract, because msg.sender is no bounded. Is it same for protokit?
in Protokit `this.transaction.sender` is always the public key that signed the transaction - its built into the framework so you dont need to do any validations yourself
pk.assertEquals(pk) --> given that you use the same variables has pretty much no effect (idk if it makes it to the circuit, but its useless)
if your goal is to restrict the proof’s usage to a certain address you need to output the PK, thats it
this checks the on-chain state matches the state in the proof, similiar to what you can do by hand with zk program output & tx sender

I think `pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey)` should also work. As long as a constraint is added it should work. 
Also, you can use `zkProgram.analyzeMethods(...)` to see the number of rows for each method and check whether adding the line increases it.
Using `signatures` is fine but the user needs to open their wallet. whereas this way anyone can use any public key, but we can assume everyone will use their own to earn rewards
pubkey.assertEquals(pubKey) means virtually nothing, you can just export the pubkey in output directly without this assertion

hmm. Just adding a pubkey param to the input of the zkProgram method creates a constraint. and adding  `pubkey.assertEquals(pubKey)` does nothing. 

But with `Field` it is different .  Adding it just to the input didn't add any new constraints, moreover adding `x.assertEquals(x)` also did not add any constraints. 😵‍💫
After adding a dummy assert like  `x.mul(x.inv()).assertEquals(1)`  it worked
all of this is pointless, you need both the public key in the output and the signature to be verified against that public key, otherwise there is no point in involving the public key at all
isn't adding the publicKey to the input the same as adding it to the output?
yes, that doesnt matter, verifying the signature does
But still one can attach arbitrary data to the proof. And I think, @Alekasndr Ivlev was trying to do that.
but that achieves exactly nothing 🤔
Quite intereting behaviour. Dont understand why pubkey create constrain by default, and Field dont
Why it didn't solve problem of reusing proof? For other one to proof, they need to generate proof by themselves and they cannot reuse this proof. Or can they?
why couldnt they? you have no idea what key was used in the proof itself, unless the data output/input of the proof is tied to a key and ideally the key itself is exposed too
if you want privacy, then you may do state proofs, but the way you described it just sounded like you need to verify and expose the user

> Quite intereting behaviour. Dont understand why pubkey create constrain by default, and Field dont
that's not true @Alekasndr Ivlev @TheDude 
adding a Field to the public output does add a constraint.
whatever way you use to count constraints (e.g. analyzeMethod) doesn't account for public outputs
but in the actual proof a constraint is added

also, `x.assertEquals(x)` is a no-op. assert equals creates a wire between two variables in the plonk constraint system (which influences the permutation argument). but wiring a variable to itself does nothing. x == x is trivially true

> As i understand zkproofs - something like this pubKey.assertEqual(pubKey), will add one more constrain. So it is + 1 linear equation.
so, just to clarify, this is incorrect. it's 0 linear equations

plonk already comes with a "permutation argument" which allows you to define equality constraints (also called "copy constraints") between any of the circuit variables. this permutation argument is fixed in size. it has the full max size even if you don't have any copy constraints, and it doesn't grow larger if you add more copy constraints
so, `x.assertEquals(y)` also doesn't increase the `rows`
Thanks for the explanation, so just adding it to the proofs input/output should work (the proof will not be maleable) . But it won't get reflected in the analyzeMethod row count.
But why does adding a publicKey to the input increases the row count?
when you add it to the public input or private input?
actually in both cases I know the reason
because there's a constraint added that the second field of the public key is boolean

certain provable data types, like `Bool`, cause constraints to be added _when they are created_. So that you know when you get a Bool, it can only be 0 or 1, and don't have to add manual checks for something like that
